Trigger - goods receipt, production, customer - gives info to the plant quality

Complaints are triggered by detected deviations from specified requirements for the respective product or service. The detector of the deviation can be an internal or external source (e.g. incoming inspection, production disruption, planned / unplanned inspections, audits, customer, feedback from the field, etc.).
In the case of new potential suppliers, the supplier must complete the delivery data questionnair.

The following risk levels are defined for all complaint types:

Risk C:
- Risk level green: low risk
- Action: Normal complaint processing (day-to-day business)
- Responsible: Complaints responsible
- Reporting: Weekly report

Risk B:
- Risk level yellow: medium risk
- Action: escalation to supervisor, who introduces an escalation meeting with the next higher organizational levels of the affected areas to find a solution. VP Quality Management is informed of the escalation. If a decision is required, the issue is presented in the Q round (if the originator is iwis), and other Q managers may be involved.
- Responsible: Supervisor of the complaint responsible
- Reporting: weekly report 

Risk A:
- Risk level red: high risk 
- Action: Escalation to VP Quality Management, who introduces an escalation meeting with the next higher organizational levels of the affected areas to find a solution. If necessary, the GF as well as Customer Internal Service / Purchasing must be informed about the escalation.
- Responsible: VP Quality Management
- Reporting: weekly report, one-pager

As described in the 8D Problem Solving Method in D1 (see also appendix 1 of WI-31.003-GEN), the complaint handler must create a kick-off meeting after the complaint has been received. 

For this purpose, the team members of the prospective 8D team from the respective departments must be invited. See Attachment 2 of WI-31.003-GEN.

The kick-off meeting is used for the ex-change of information, the possible expansion and concretization of the 8D team and the initial distribu-tion of tasks. These could be, for example, tracing and narrowing down the problem, checking the delivery schedules and the inventory, and initiating immediate measures.

PSM committee:
PSCR + Divisions heads 
- Production
- R&D
- Quality
- Purchasing
- Sales

Effectiveness evaluation by employees
 In Germany via SAP

Result interpretation of the potential analysis according to VDA 6.3:

green = approved applicant
The applicant has the potential to implement the requirements to the requested extent and can be consulted for an assignment. An assignment is possible without restriction.

yellow = controlled applicant
For the requested scope only a conditional recommendation for the assignment of contract can be made. To achieve a green rating, the supplier must implement a coordinated action plan.

red = blocked applicant
A project assignment is not possible.

MMR to be conducted within the first 60 days of the following calendar year. First 30 days will be used for year end closing and data finalization. Second 30 days + 15 will be used for MMR report preparation. All open issues addressed in MMR are required to be closed within 90 days of formal MMR with senior management. This will result within closure of all previous years open issues within 180 days of year end closing.

Monitoring process re-qualification monthly in the Q-round:

participants:

GF
Management QM
Plant Quality Management
Production

Extract from IATF 8.7.1.1 Special customer releases: Before a non-conforming product can be used, processed or repaired in its current state, the organization must obtain the customer's approval. If sub-components are to be reused in the manufacturing process, this reuse must be clearly communicated to the customer in the corresponding special releases or deviation approvals. If the product continues to conform to the specifications agreed with the customer, the change committee may change the default setting of the customer information in the change request to "customer information required no".
Creation of production orders for planned requalification simultaneously with series prod. orders.

Preparation of re-qualification plan taking into account WI 31004 GEN and CSR to be completed by the end of the year.

Distribution list:

- Planning
- Production
- Metrology
- Laboratory
- Product Testing
Delivery to plant quality must take place by the end of October.

The change committee, the requester and the departments define the change implementation. The following are determined jointly: Overall person responsible, work packages with target dates and responsible persons. The implementation of changes is structured according to the requirements, not necessarily according to standard phases.

The standard phases of a change are:
- Planning: Here all information necessary for the evaluation and planning of the changes by the change committee is obtained.
- Feasibility: Here the feasibility of a change is examined.
- Validation: This phase serves to prove the suitability of modified parts or processes.
- Introduction: In this phase, the change is introduced into series production (usually by means of F098 by the project team).
The verification of feasibility shall be documented.
Are the implemented measures effective to prevent a recurrence of the causal error of the nonconformity?

Each process shall be audited at least once every three years. In addition, due to current circumstances (e.g. internal and external performance trends such as complaints, special customer status, critical processes), the audit program has to be adapted.

The auditors are assigned to the respective audits on the basis of their qualification / competence.

In order to preserve the auditor competence, each auditor should perform or accompany at least one audit per year.

Cost absorption:

If the supplier 
unexpectedly
rejects costs, is 
the sorting has 
to be started anyway to ensure delivery capability 
to customers. 
Cost clarification 
takes place afterwards via 
Purchasing

See deadline specifications in WI-31.003GEN.

All relevant costs incurred in connection with the processing of complaints shall be recorded in Babtec and will be charged afterwards by FI according to the causer.

Note: In Germany, customer complaints and related supplier complaints are closed by the Head of Warranty and Customer Complaints.

The output of the 8D problem solving method is the fully completed 8D report, supplemented, if necessary, by various support and evidence documents.
If the complaint handler or the customer does not agree with the contents of the 8D Report or if it is not complete, the causer (e.g. supplier or production) or the 8D team must initiate its improvement.

An evaluation table is available as an aid to the respective complaint handler and the 8D team to check and evaluate the quality of the 8D procedure during the complaint processing or before the conclusion of the 8D report (see evaluation matrix in F183).

The open complaint in Babtec must be kept up to date by the 8D team throughout the entire processing period. All relevant information and files must be stored in Babtec (including feedback from external suppliers).

8D reports from suppliers must also be filed in Babtec. In this case, the basic information from the 8D report (such as immediate measures, cause, counter- and preventive measures with the deadlines) shall be transferred to Babtec in accordance with the defined tree structure.

If the complaints processing for the external customer has to be documented in a customer portal (B2B), it must be maintained by the responsible complaints handler in accordance with the set deadline.

Complaint responsible = 8D moderator / method expert
Causer = Team leader (Prozess responsible)

During the processing of complaints the causer-pays principle prevails, however the 8D procedure is always based on interdisciplinary teamwork. The composition of the 8D team (iwis intern) and the roles within the team are regulated in attachment #2 of WI-31.003-GEN.

Supplier complaints are handled by the responsible complaints handler. If required, supplier development or project quality department from D5 onwards is to be integrated for a plausibility check of the cause analysis and the defined action plan, as well as for an effectiveness check of the implemented actions on site. In case of escalation, the purchasing department must also be involved.

The supplier is informed about the complaint with a standard letter. See template in Babtec (Print menu on articel level).
If the causer cannot be clearly assigned in a first step, suitable analyses (e.g. analysis of damaged parts in the laboratory) must be initiated by the complaint responsible.

A complaint is eligible if the complaint was caused and confirmed by iwis or by one of its suppliers.
(Examples of unjustified complaints: no iwis product, or clear transport damage, or error due to customer's wrong action...).

Specific requirements from the respective customer regarding documentation of complaints processing must always be taken into account. 

Complaints must be recorded and processed in Babtec.

After receiving the message about non-conformity, the responsible complaint responsible starts the complaint processing procedure (create a new complaint in Babtec Complaints module). Select the complaint type according to WI-31.003-GEN. >> see also the actual Babtec training materials.

Only one defect or one part number may be listed under a complaint number. Complaints concerning several defects on the same product, or several products with the same defect pattern must be created under different complaint numbers, whereby these complaints can be linked with each other. (Exception: field complaints, here several part numbers can be entered under one complaint number).¬†

When creating a new complaint, the complaint responsible must check the error for repetition. Repeat errors must be marked accordingly in Babtec.

Complaints about products which have not yet been approved by iwis (in case of purchased part) or by the customer (prototype or pre-series part) will be handled in full by the responsible project quality engineer.

The responsibility for processing complaints is transferred to the responsible complaint handler after the initial sample approval by the customer. The handover takes place during the QM series introduction discussion (see checklist F321) between project and plant quality as well as CCM.
In the series start-up phase (up to QG5), the project team (project manager, project quality engineer, design engineer and, if necessary, systems engineer) should be involved in complaints processing. Later, it is sufficient if only the project quality engineer is in-formed about the (customer) complaint and if necessary involved in the processing.
The triggered complaint should be recorded according to the trigger matrix (WI-31.003-GEN) in Babtec.
A special release by the site PSCR (Product Safety and Conformity Representative) for design / process FMEA with significance > 8 shall be obtained and documented.
A special release by the site PSCR (Product Safety and Conformity Representative) for design / process FMEA with significance > 8 shall be obtained and documented.
A special release by the site PSCR (Product Safety and Conformity Representative) for design / process FMEA with significance > 8 shall be obtained and documented.

Initiate process Product safety according to WI-10.050-GEN

A special release by the site PSCR (Product Safety and Conformity Representative) for design / process FMEA with significance > 8 shall be obtained and documented.

Are there points in the product FMEA with severity > 8:

"Extremely serious error that impairs safety [...]" (according to WI-10.304-GEN)

An appropriate root cause analysis must be carried out for each deviation. F183 Problem solving methods can be used as an aid here. The cause analysis for the respective deviation must be stored in the Babtec audit module - either in the provided fields or with the help of the F183. period for creation The cause analysis including measures should be prepared promptly. A reasonable period of time is one week. --> the time schedule for the processing of the measures to the deviations begins with the day of the audit!
Process audit in accordance with VDA 6.3 - Used in production - Only VDA 6.3 - P6 is audited. Customer specific requirement VW: - Additional Formul Q F√§higkeiten, Appendix 8 must be considered.

Efficiency and expediency of the management system including the implementation of customer specific requirements at all areas of iwis mo-torsysteme are verified by internal audits (S/P). Identified defects and deviations will be docu-mented and adjusted. The effectiveness of cor-rective and preventive actions is verified by them. Among other things the results of internal audits are a basis for the senior management to evaluate the management system.

Review of the lessons learned database with regard to the preferred concept.

- Were there any problems with the concept in the past?
- How should any anomalies/risks be dealt with?
- Consideration in FMEA

Order of PSO parts (externally) supplier and (internally) plant (e.g. chain and chain tensioner). Information about quantities (internal) must be determined by quality taking into account the advanced quality planning.
Drawing approval according to WI-40.008-GEN (Status P)

Make or Buy - review both for production of the individual parts and assembly of the entire product.

Make or Buy - the decision is made in phase 3.
Drawing approval according to WI-40.008-GEN (Status Q)

The DVP contains the following elements
- Type + short description of tests + test objective
- Timetable for trials 
- required resources (internal+external)

Perform a product and process review based on the findings from the customer project (if necessary update basic FMEA (process / product), entry in lessons learned data base, update DVP template, start Change Management,...)
Resources (staff / infrastructure), planning and confirmation by approval project request
Create/complete the development request. Approval usually takes place in QPI 1.

Preparation of specifications for the respective product / technology. A draft is sufficient at this point. At this point, the requirement specification should be largely independent of a possible solution and only contain the functions to be fulfilled.

Create the business case to verify the economics of the product.

- At what point does the product/technology generate a profit?
- How much should the development cost to get the product/technology into the profit zone in a reasonable time?
Creation advanced quality planning concerning external deliveries acc. to WI-31.131-GEN
Preparation of the specifications for the operating resources for the internal production volumes
Making any changes to the drawings (for prototypes)

Defining a concept --> freezing the concept in order to enter validation in PI PEP Phase 3.
Select external development partner if required
Creation of the product FMEA for the product / technology incl. risk assessment, creation of remedial measures and entry of responsibilities incl. schedule.
Derivation of the specifications for the product / technology. Derived from the specifications and results of the concept and patent investigations as well as any existing customer requirements.
Cost assessment of components manufactured by iwis itself. The cost evaluation is carried out by the corresponding manufacturing planner.

Conducting concept studies to examine the suitability of the concepts, e.g.:
- Functional tests

Order of components via the purchasing department

Testing of the prototype parts (geometry, WOB,...) is independently controlled by the product developer according to the requirements.
Review and, if necessary, revision of the specification sheet
After completion of the NTF-process, relevant results are compiled into a report and sent to the customer. Further handling of the damaged parts is customer specific.

If a fault is found during the NTF process that can be identified with an improved testing procedure during Stage 1 / Stage 2, the testing procedure shall be improved if possible. Changes to the testing procedure need to be approved by the customer.

Once the strategy is decided on, the NTF-process is executed according to the NTF-checklist. The Results are documented in the NTF Checklist and the NTF report. Detailed information about the testing method, statisctical Methods, etc. are to be saved in the respective sub-folder of the NTF project. Intermittent results are to be shared with the customer on a regular basis.

Ist die Mitarbeit des Kunden/OEM erforderlich, so muss er unter Mitteilung der bisher ausgearbeiteten Strategie aufgefordert werden, sich am NTF-prozess zu beteiligen. Im Rahmen der dann folgenden Absprachen m√ºssen gemeinsame Datenanalysen, Schadteilanalysen und weitere, je nach Fall notwendige, Ma√ünahmen abgestimmt werden. Sollten OEM-spezifische Anforderungen existieren, so sind diese im Rahen des NTF-Prozesses zu ber√ºcksichtigen. OEM-Anforderungen abweichend vom VDA NTF-Prozess finden sich im GW-Handbuch Kapitel 2.9 Besonderheiten NTF-Prozess der einzelnen OEM. If the customers assistance is required, he ist required to assist in the NTF-process. If the customer has specific requirements for the process they need to be fullfilled,OEM requirements deviating from VDA MTF can be found in the warranty handbook chapter 2.9.

In this step, materials, methods and the people involved in the NTF-process are defined. Technical an personal capacaties need to be estimated and requested. If it can be assumed that the faulty part was cause/influenced by the customer, he needs to be included in the process. This is epecially important when test-equipment, test cars and the service net has to be provided by the sucotmer

During this process step, all available information regarding the NTF-process are collected. With this, product and process related analyses are possible. Examples for this are: Warrantydata from the OEM, sales numbers, vehicle information incl. service and repair instructions, diagnostics result. online forum and internet search, information about the production process, DVP, sector and competitor benchmarks, lessons learned from FMEAs. Further information can be found in the warranty handbook chapter 2.

Ist eine NTF-Projekt durchzuf√ºhren, wird durch den Warranty Mitarbeiter auf dem Server ein Projektordner erstellt, in dem folgende Unterstruktur vorliegt: - Kommunikation - Daten iwis - Daten OEM - Daten externe Quellen - Analysen Die Benennung von Ordnern, Dokumenten etc. richtet sich nach dem Leitfaden NTF-Prozess iwis aus dem Gew√§hrleistungshandbuch.
Triggers are safety relevance, high cost, absolut/relative frequencies, run-in issues, climate anomalies, regional/cultural topics, customer specific requirements, etc.

First, data is searched for NTF criteria accoriding to iwis NTF-guidelines (incl. OEM requirements). This includes for example reaching defined NTF-quotas, in-field problems after production start-up or significant problems for the end user (e.g. break downs). Results are documented in NTF-reports according to the template. Further information can be found in the warranty handbook chapter 2.
After a claim is succesfully closed, it is archived in iwis¬¥ Lessons Learned Database. A short summary of the claim incl. what went good, what went bad helps prevent similar problems in the future

If information of the customer is necessary for safety and escalation reasons, or to get more data, further actions need to be coordination. Especially communication rules need to be follower to prevent undapproved information from being spread. Further data analysis, statistics, etc. are done in close contact with the customer. Suggested procedures, chec lists and guide can be found in the Warranty hand book.

If an escalation is necessary (e.g. recall, serial damange, etc.), establishing a Task Force ensures that interdisciplinary know-how is available and that the case can be dealt with with regards to liability and financial factors. Structure of the Task Force, suggested procedures, actions, checklist and tips can be found in the Warranty Handbook chapter 3-5
The leader QM cann decide for an unplanned intervention by the in-field failure if necessary.
Triggers are safety relevance, high cost, absolut/relative frequencies, run-in issues, climate anomalies, regional/cultural topics, customer specific requirements, etc.

During extended data analysis, all available information on field performance is analysed further. Pivotanalyses to isolate critical markets, customers, regions, sesions, etc. are made. Furthermore, parts that showed anomalies during previous analyses are examines more thoroughly by for examaple layered line graphs, Weibull Analysis, stress analysis or reliability prediction. Analysis methods, necessary software and tips for data analysis can be found in the warranty handbook chapters 3, 4 and 5.

Based on the analyses, warranty KPIs are calculated to allow KPI-based process control. E.g. number of new claims per customer, rejected/accepted claim ratio, warranty rate, top error pattern. Warranty KPIs can be found in the Warranty Handbook chapter 6.
evidence documents are posted in SAP to the relevant cost centers
8.4 Control of external provided processes, products and services
8.3 Design and Development of Products and Services
warranty claim processing according to customer requirements
store damaged parts according to customer requirements
decide based on the specific customer, wether parts are stored or sent back
warranty claim is rejected at the customer
investigate if iwis is resposible for the fault
Cofirm Warranty Claim in supplier portal (Daimler only). If no portal is available, no confirmation will be given.
heat treatment with inspection and approval
NOK products already shipped to customer?
In this step, corrected evidence documents are validated once more. Rules are identical with initial validation steps. Further information can be found in the Warranty Handbook chapter 8.

If the customer is not willing to change his claim based on provided documents (objection list), further analysis is necesarry to strengthen iwis¬¥ position. Further analysis options can be found in the Warranty Handbook chapter 4.
In this step, objection is given to the unjustified advance information. Contact persons at the OEM, deadlines and further information can be found in the Warranty Handbook chapter 9.

For data validation, data in Babtex is validated based on specified rules. Objection criteria for example are Out of Warranty, missing case data (VIN, registration date, mileage, error code,...) or unplausible entries (i.e. mileage too high, production date past registration date, etc.). Babtec automatically creates an objection list with all rejectable claims. Further information can be found in the Warranty Handbook chapter 8.

Processed data in .csv format, together with further evidence if available, are imported into Babtec and processed further. For example, this processing includes matching customer to iwis parts numbers. Further information can be found in the Warranty Handbook chapter 8
For customer specific data processing, the OEM¬¥s raw data is formated in a way that can be imported into Babtec. Specific rules can be found in the warranty handbook chapter 9
Evidence documents can be found on the OEMs supplier portal. Login information can be found in the warranty handbook (chapter 9).

Definitions: Babtec: CAQ system, incl. modules for complaint and action management. 8D report: The 8D report documents the complaint process in a clearly summarized way together with the corresponding corrective actions. It is created by an 8D team. Complaint handler: responsible employee of the QM organization who starts the new complaint process, creates it in Babtec and follows it to the end. The complaint handler varies depending on the complaint type (such as customer, field, supplier, internal or intercompany complaint). He ensures the correct documentation of complaint processing in the CAQ system and ensures that deadlines are met. He is part of the 8D team and methodically supports teamwork as an 8D moderator. CCM: (Customer Complaint Manager): Complaint handler responsible for customer complaints. Supplier: In the sense of this work instruction, a supplier of both internal and external products and / or services. Customer: Is in the sense of this work instruction both internal and external customer of products and / or services. A defect is the non-compliance with the specified requirements. The non-conformity of the product / process (the defect) is detected either at incoming inspection or after the last process step (final inspec-tion in production, in the product audit, in downstream areas or in the worst case at the customer), and thus triggers a complaint. Repeated defect: defined under the following condi-tions: 1. the same part (base: part number) 2. the complaint went to the same (int. / ext.) supplier. 3. both complaints have the same error symptom (basis: error description of the customer). 4 The first complaint about this combination has al-ready been completed. If all four conditions apply, this is a case of a repeating defect. Follow-up defect: if the conditions 1.-3. of a repeating defect are true, but the first complaint is not yet closed.

Either the detected deviation is in tolerance

Or the deviation is regarded as uncritical - Deviation Request!

Purpose:

Description of the procedure for handling complaints if quality-relevant deviations are identified in the product / process. The aim is to eliminate the reason for the complaint as quickly and effectively as possible and to avoid a recurrence of the defect. In addition, the complete documentation of the problem solution should ensure the traceability of the fault elimination process.

Area of application:

This description applies to 
- for all locations of iwis engine systems worldwide. 
- only for complaints which are triggered by product or process-related quality defects from prototyp-phase pre-series, series and warranty.
- for complaints that must be processed using the 8D procedure. (In the case of prototype, pre-series and warranty claims, not all steps of the 8D procedure must necessarily be carried out).
 
If the customer only requests an informal statement without detailed analysis or 8D report, the feedback can be given by e-mail / presentation, and no complaint must be recorded in Babtec.
Root cause analysis methods and process can be found in Sharepoint

Execution of all processes requires suitable employees. The aim of the human resource management is the provision of required employees with the required knowledge. Planning of trainings to maintain or expand employee knowledge and checking their effectiveness is also part of this.

Site PSCR requires the reaction / prevention measures from the process owner / process representative.
The respective process owner / process representative is responsible for the definition and effective implementation of appropriate measures.

Events are:
- Non-compliance with safety-relevant product characteristics, or
- Non-compliance with control measures on safety-relevant product features in the production process.

Examples of information sources:
- internal / external (customer) complaints
- Results from product audit / requalification test
- supplier complaints
- incoming goods inspection
- Field complaints / warranty
- OEM information
- Competition Information
- RAPEX - Rapid Exchange of Information System
- Design product liability / safety in relevant legal proceedings
- ...
